lexUnit.name: toughness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or state of being tough

sentence.text: He was slight and short-sighted , with a gentle smile that belied an amazing toughness and an ability to withstand cold that was to beggar our belief .
When the two are put together however , the result is a material which is sold in large quantities primarily on account of its extreme toughness .
The king 's son had a young man 's idea of a joke : he thought he 'd test the courage and much-vaunted toughness of Albuin .
We continued into Zanskar safely , with their help -- never ceasing to be amazed at their incredible toughness .
PMMA began to replace glass in the 1940s because of its toughness , its optical properties and its physiological inactivity -- also it was easily processed by using existing turning techniques .
A low-velocity round tumbling against the toughness of the skull bone .
Nor do I accept that such feelings are a sign of weakness , provided that they are accompanied by an inner toughness where necessary and justified . "
Patsy and Jimmy were both showing a bit of their dad 's toughness .
The miners and the police share occupational cultures in which solidarity and toughness were highly valued .
Crown masonry paints are solventbased for extra toughness .
Like all his colleagues he dismisses their legendary toughness .
Tatra 's trucks have a reputation among lorry drivers for great toughness .
He can not put his finger on what has gone wrong on their travels -- the times of arrival at the ground have even been varied -- and now is the time for mental toughness .
Thanks to their size , toughness , and extreme ferocity war boars make excellent mounts for Orc warriors .
The production price and toughness of the cutlery depends on the proportions in which the metals are mixed .
Fine grain size also improves the mechanical strength and toughness of the alumina .
